key_mistakes.reason: This move is passive and doesn't contest the center. Playing e5 would have maintained central control.
This allows White to solidify their center without contest. Developing a piece with Bf5 would have been better.
This move exposes the queen too early and doesn't contribute to development. Developing with e6 would have been more prudent.
This allows the opponent to gain a strong initiative with tempo. Keeping the pawn with b4 would have avoided immediate threats.
This weakens the kingside and exposes the king to potential attacks. Developing with a4 would have been safer.
This move neglects king safety and development. Nf3 would have supported the center and improved coordination.
This move loses a queen in exchange for minor material advantage. Retreating with Qd1 would have avoided the blunder.
This move offers a knight for free and doesn't contribute to an effective attack. Playing h4 would have been more strategic.
This move places the king in a vulnerable position without any defensive compensation. Retreating to Kh2 was safer.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with your pawns and pieces in the opening.
Prioritize king safety before launching an attack.
Develop your pieces efficiently to ensure they are well-coordinated.
Avoid exposing your major pieces early in the game without adequate support.
Be mindful of pawn structure changes and their impact on your position.
Consider the consequences of weakening your king's position with pawn moves.
